At 6.8 oz, the can is thicker than a Red Bull can (8.4 oz), and a tad bit shorter. Definitely worth a try!

review_title: Great flavor, but give us an unsweetened espresso
review_text: This is the second illy issimo coffee drink that I've tried, and both of them have had a great bold taste. Both were also full of sugar. I don't really enjoy my coffee with sugar in it, but I think if illy issimo would come out with a full-bodied espresso drink that has no sweetener whatsoever in it, suitable for using in place of pulled espresso shots for making one's own lattes or for splitting a can in espresso cups, that would be a hit and would be something I might buy to have on hand to serve to guests.

I made the mistake of taking my first sip of this coffee after tasting something sweet. It's bitter! But tasting it later I came to appreciate the flavor.

Unlike a lot of canned/bottled coffee drinks, to me this tasted like real coffee. Nice and strong, not too sweet. If you put a lot of sweet-and-white in your coffee, you will find this drink unbearably bitter, in that case I recommend the Cappucino version of the same brand.

Nutrition facts: 50 calories in the can, 20mg sodium, 12 carbs (10g sugars, 1g fiber) -- which isn't bad. Caffeine content is 155 mg in the 6.8 fl oz. The ingredients list coffee, sugar, potassium bicarbonate, and potassium citrate. No milk, which is healthier, and I prefer that because I'm lactose intolerant. It also means it lasts longer -- the best-by date on my sample can is Sept. '12 (received April).

The can lists this nice coffee as a Product of Denmark. I've tasted coffee in Denmark, and I can't dispute that, though I can tell you this method is a whole lot cheaper.

I drank it cold and I really enjoyed this coffee. I would really like to get more... but it is a bit pricy. If you are on the go a lot this is an easy solution.

review_title: Convenient small can of espresso drink
review_text:
I enjoy just about any coffee, and I liked the illy issimo caffe Italian Espresso Style Coffee Drink too. It does have a bit of a bitter taste, even though the ingredients include sugar. So it's not a real sweet drink. I liked the strong, somewhat bitter taste of it, even though my favorite coffee drinks are mocha style beverages (both hot and cold).

I refrigerated the can before drinking, and it was a nice quick cold coffee beverage. However, I am used to drinking large cups of coffee, so the small 6.8 oz. can seemed too small, and I finished it off pretty quick. The nice thing about the small can is you can take these with you just about anywhere. So they are very convenient.

I'd recommend to people who like iced espresso style coffee drinks that have a bit of sweetness, but remain a bit bitter and who want very convenient small servings that can be taken just about anywhere.

review_title: Strong Flavor and Close to Real Espresso Taste
review_text: I love espresso, the stronger the better.  I was pleasantly surprised at the rich taste and strong flavor that this Illy drink possesses.  It is not like the usual bottled or canned coffee drink.  It tastes like it just came out of the espresso machine.  There's a slight sweetness, but just a touch so as to make the drink not bitter.  If you can't get to a real espresso stand, then I highly recommend this drink as a good substitution.

I am sure there is a market for this canned coffee drink, but I am not part of the market! It tasted very bitter to me, and I could not detect any sweetness, even though the information on the can stated that it contained sugar. I am not sure why the instructions say not to shake the can before opening, but I decided for once to follow instructions...just in case, you know. My guess is that this product is popular among those who already enjoy espresso rather than just accept a cup when it is pressed upon them. One can drink it at room temperature or cold -- I drank my half a can at room temperature before disposing of it,  but upon reflection I probably should have chilled the rest to see if that improved the flavor.

Unlike illy issimo Coffee Drink, Cappuccino, 8.45-Ounce Cans (Pack of 12), which I enjoyed, this "coffee drink" was terrible. It had a very strong bitter taste like the coffee at the bottom of the pot that had cooled hours ago.

The Cappuccino flavor was great, this one I couldn't finish.

review_title: Do you like iced coffee? This is for you!
review_text: If you really liked coffee or want an alternative for a hot day, this is it. Refrigerate it and/or pour over ice and it is ideal for that hot day relaxing. It is sweetened, but me personally like a bit more sugar. It tastes just like coffee and is not overly strong. I like the fact that it is a single seving can, so I don't have to make an entire pot off coffee. It is easy enough to put in the refrigerator and grab when needed, or take to go while on the run.

Yes, I'm a coffee junkie. I really liked this drink. Smooth and just sweet enough. It's not really that strong so unless you like really weak coffee, I dont recommend putting it over ice.

The only problem I had with this drink is the 6.8oz can wasn't big enough.

Thank you.
MEF

I have to admit that I am not a big fan of coffee, but if it's the right product, I usually love it. Like others who have reviewed this product, I really like the Starbucks bottled frappacinos you can buy in stores, and I figured that I would like this product due to the similarities. This product isn't terrible, but it's not really good either. It had a strong coffee flavor, a little stronger than I like, but there was also a weird aftertaste. I'd have to describe it was sour and bitter, but it wasn't the kind of sour/bitter aftertaste you get sometimes with "bargain" coffee brands; it had a unique bad aftertase all its own. I did like the jolt of energy that it had, but I could get the same amount of energy from tastier drinks. It seems like a lot of people like it, so I don't want to put it down entirely, but for me personally, it wasn't something that I enjoyed.

This is just like drinking a can of plain, strong black coffee.  There is sugar in it, so it's slightly sweet, but don't buy this expecting a nice sweet and creamy coffee drink.  It says on the side of the can "Italian Espresso Style Coffee Drink" and that's what it is.  I don't really know what "Caffe" means, but this drink is nothing but black coffee with sugar in it.  If you know that's what you want, I'm sure you'll be happy with it.  It has a nice smooth taste and my husband and I both really liked it.

"How can something with sugar as the second ingredient be so incredibly bitter?" said my husband after his first taste. I couldn't answer, my mouth was puckered like an old lady at a lemon eating contest.

Hubby reached for the Hazelnut creamer, poured a little in, and we both agreed it made a huge improvement.

I realize there are plenty of manly men out there who like their coffee black and their women strong, or something like that, but no one in our family resembles that description. However, for people who like cold black coffee, this is probably a very refreshing drink. For a generation brought up on super-sweet flavored and whip-cream-topped coffee concoctions, I doubt this will be a hit. Unless they use it as a challenge, like eating a teaspoon of cinnamon, or drinking Sriracha sauce straight from the bottle.

As a night worker, I'm always looking for a new beverage with 'zip' in it. Almost any coffee product will do. It helps, though, to be fully cognizant of what's in the can before you make expectations.

While I guess I was thinking this was going to be another in the long line of Starbucks-type creamy and sweet coffee drinks, this is nothing of the kind. There is just enough sweet to take off the bitter, but this is very much an espresso-type drink - which, if I'd bothered to read the can, I would have realized.

Good enough for what it was - and it did hike my alertness somewhat - it comes in a small can, nowhere near the size of even a regular canned coffee. The flavor was okay, but for what stuff goes for these days, the product could be a little more generous.

review_title: Great as a mixer or in recipes
review_text: I don't usually drink espresso so this was a bit strong for me.  The flavor, however, was very good.  I drank part of it straight and mixed the rest with some milk and ice.  I preferred it prepared as an iced latte.  That is the great feature of this drink, it gives you so many options.  You can use it in recipes (Tiramisu comes to mind), frappes, iced lattes, lattes or just straight as a slightly sweet espresso. This would also be a great mixer for coffee cocktails. It would be nice to keep a can or two on hand in the pantry.  I personally probably wouldn't just be grabbing a can to drink straight because that's just not my thing but for anyone who likes strong coffee flavor it would be a treat.  If you're going on a camping trip, hike or to any location that you won't be able to brew a cup, packing a can of illy issimo would be a wonderful alternative.

I had tried the cappuccino version of this brand, and it was not delicious.  This product is more just coffee and sugar with fewer chemical additives.  It was strong and dark out of the can, and after two minutes in the microwave along with some milk, it was quite drinkable.  I'm not a super fan of cold coffee, so I can't comment on how well it would work as that.  It did have a European coffee flair.

review_title: Not very good...had that stale coffee taste.
review_text: I drink a good bit of coffee, most of it iced, so I was expecting something decent with the illy issimo Coffee drink. To my dismay, I didn't like it...at all. It's basically an iced, sweetened coffee drink around espresso strength. The drink had that stale, "I've been sitting for a while" coffee taste that is best poured down a drain. The sweetness is about right (not cloying or overpowering) and it definitely tastes like espresso, but it just doesn't taste like fresh brewed (maybe yesterday). I know it comes in a can and technically can't be fresh, but I've tasted similar coffee drinks that didn't have that stale, skunky taste. It gets two stars for giving a decent energy/caffeine boost, but the taste makes it impossible to recommend.

I found this drink to be bitter, sharp, and almost flavorless. I was very surprised after really liking another flavor in this brand (Maybe I got a bad can?). I even had my husband try it to share his thoughts and he like I was not a fan either. It's a shame because of all the nutritional benefits and convenience of taking along this drink with you.

Other than the benefit of caffeine, this really is not a very good drink. If you compare it to other competitors (namely the at-home Starbucks drinks), it's vastly inferior in just about every category. The taste is mediocre and not pleasant. The smell keeps its metallic odor even after pouring it into a different glass. The value isn't there, either.

Overall, it's a very disappointing drink.

I'm usually not a fan of canned coffee drinks, but wanted to try this since I love Illy espresso beans. While the canned version can't compare to a properly pulled shot of espresso, this is a pretty tasty alternative. Good flavor without the odd after-taste I've experienced with other canned coffee drinks.

I tried it right out of the can (room temp) and over ice. I found it more enjoyable straight from the can.

My only complaint is that it's a bit on the sweet side. I never add sugar to my coffee so I'm sensitive to any level of sweetness. Others may find the sweetness level to be fine.

But, even with the sweetness, I would certainly get this again. It provides for a tasty afternoon pickup.

This illy issimo Caffe Coffee Drink has a strong coffee flavor that would normally be a plus since I like "bold" coffee, but the very bitter aftertaste is too much to make this enjoyable. Just to be sure it wasn't me, my coffee loving daughter also tried it and while she liked it more than I did, she said it is not a drink she would seek out again.

This just misses the mark for us.

CFH

I have been drinking the Starbucks coffee's for years (the little double shot espresso can, similar to this one)

I like this one much more, there is no aftertaste, I really like it, I will get this product instead of the Starbucks if I need to choose between those two.

This product taste much better

This is a small can of espresso but more than enough to satisfy my coffee craving. It's not an iced frappicino type drink. There is no cream or milk and only barely enough sweetness. But the coffee is rich and STRONG. It is bitter but adding about 1/2 teaspoon sugar fixed that. I guess you could heat it for a hot espresso but iced it was awesome.

review_title: You Have To REALLY Like Iced Esspresso To Drink This
review_text:
I sampled the caffe flavor. illy issimo comes in five flavors: caffe, caffe no sugar, cappuccino, mochaccino, and latte macchiato.

Unless you like iced coffee to begin with, and then iced espresso to boot, you probably won't like this product. This has no dairy type ingredients, so you will either need to drink this "black" or add something to it. I tried it straight out of the can into a glass, chilled. It was really strong, as in very bitter.

I softened it a bit by adding some skim milk and sugar. Even though this is sweetened with beet sugar, the bitterness far overpowers any hint of sweetness. I added about 3 teaspoons of sugar, and then used about two ounces of milk mixed with this 6.8 ounce can. That made it more palatable. I then added some crushed ice and poured some over the ice. Better yet.

All in all I would say this is for only hard core iced coffee drinkers. If you lean more toward a sweet coffee with lots of sugar, this probably isn't going to be up your alley.

But if you are an iced coffee drinker and like the bold taste of espresso, you might want to give this a whirl.

This coffee beverage tasted pretty good...it was strong but slightly bitter so I couldn't see myself drinking it every day.  The caffeine gave me a nice morning boost.  The calories aren't too bad for this kind of drink.

If you've read any of my other reviews regarding coffee, you know I'm a coffee lover... and I like it strong!  The illy issimo caffé Italian espresso style coffee drink met my expectations.  I divided my 6.8 fl oz can into 3 portions, so that I could try it in different ways.  I had it in a mug after warming it in the microwave and then warmed with some milk, as well as in a glass over ice.  Since it is a little sweet, I preferred it with milk or over ice.  However, it's not bad alone, and would probably be good chilled straight out of the can.  It is made primarily with natural Arabica beans and sugar, with 50 calories and 12g carb per serving.  It also has 20 mg of sodium and 155 mg of caffeine.  I like it!

Normally words like "coffee in a can" would make me want to punch a kitten in the mouth but this had a truly nice effect. It made me feel calmer, less shaky, more like my normal, coffee-needing self. Happier. Granted, i would need a box of them to get through a day but I guess that is splitting hairs because the product has a nice taste, pleasant even, and it is easy to store and hide from my friends who would take and drink it - and then no review. all this combined for an experience that said I was really happy, surprised even, by just how good it tasted.
no kittens were harmed by end of the review.

I really love the intense coffee taste to this drink. It's like an ice cold Italian espresso with a little cream and sugar. The ingredients are all natural (no preservatives) and the 155 mg. of caffeine is a nice energy boost. One can is only 50 calories. Love it!

I'm a fan of coffee, but I like it sweet. I want to taste the flavor of the coffee, but the sweetness adds depth and richness to it. This little coffee in a can was good, but not as sweet as I prefer.

review_title: Great pick-me-up on a hot afternoon!
review_text:
This is a great espresso with just a hint of sweetness. If you are an espresso drinker this is for you. If you like lattes, cappucinos, and such, look elsewhere, this has no milk or flavorings, it's just pure, smooth espresso.

My preference for anything other than my morning coffee from my Keurig is hot in the winter and ice cold in the summer. Today's temperature touched 100 so ice cold was the order of the day. I have a special fast chill compartment in my refrigerator that cools items quickly to 34 degrees and after 4 hours in there I put the can in the freezer for 5 minutes. It was icy cold the way I like it. THe espresso is strong and bold without bitterness. I liked the slight hint of sweetness as I find many coffee drinks to be too sweet for my taste but the Illy Issimo was spot on. Compared to a Starbucks Double Shot the Illy has a better, more well-rounded flavor.

Ok, I raved about the product so why only 4 stars? The price! In this age of Starbucks, etc., we are getting used to paying astronomical prices for coffee. Folks, this is good espresso and convenient in the can but it is still coffee. I guess we like to pay for convenience. I could make Illy espresso in my Gaggia Baby for pennies a shot but sticking a can in the fridge is more convenient. Bottom line, it's still coffee, a very nice espresso, but still coffee.

I had high hopes for this drink despite the fact that I prefer unsweetened drinks.  I poured it in the glass and was unhappy with how dark it was.  I took a sip and choked.  This drink is bitter and to me undrinkable.  It was like drinking the bottom of a burned pot of coffee.  I tried adding milk to the cup but it didn't lighten the color at all.  Even with the milk I couldn't drink it and down the drain it went.  Awful!

This was an enjoyable and refreshing treat on a hot summer day.  I poured the coffee over ice to enjoy it colder and it was very good.  It has a strong, bold coffee flavor, not bitter, and is slightly sweetened but not very sweet.  You could always add more sweetener to suit your taste, but I personally didn't find it necessary.  At only 50 calories a can this is a nice light drink.

First tried this in a glass straight from the can. Strong aromatic coffee smell, good dark color, strong coffee flavor with a hint of sweetness.
Next, I heated a cup up in the microwave. Again, same consistent results. It was surprisingly good for "canned" coffee.

Illy Issimo Coffee Drink is really good. I especially like it iced in this hot weather. It gives me a nice caffine boost. During the low part of my day (early Afternoon) it is a nice pic me up! It also tastes pretty good.If you like a deep rich coffee you will love it.Try it iced.

My husband loves espresso.  We have a bialetti that he regularly uses at home to make espresso here.  I was once told by an espresso lover that a bialetti is the best way to make espresso.  All that to say-- it is something that my husband loves.  Typically, we use illy espresso to make his espressos at home, so he was excited to try this.  He has enjoyed Starbucks Doubleshots, but truly prefers a smooth espresso with just a touch of sugar.  This illy fits that bill!  The Starbucks doubleshot has a touch of cream in it--my husband explained to me that it needs that bit of cream in order to give it a smooth flavor.  The illy doesn't need it.  It's so smooth without the cream that it's better than a doubleshot.  And for a 12 pack, it's $13 cheaper for 12 ($36 vs. $23).  That sounds a lot better to me!

review_title: Not impressed! Just regular strong black coffe with a little sugar.
review_text: I love coffee of all kinds and flavors, but this was a dissapointment. I expected it ti have a stronger richer flavor, but it jsut tasted like regualr old coffee with a little sugar.  If that is what you want go for it.

review_title: Not much flavor and very bland.
review_text:
This drink barely passes for a coffee drink. It is very light in flavor with minimal coffee essence, despite the first ingredient being coffee. It has very little flavor and still less of what I would call espresso. It also has a somewhat odd after taste, sort of bitter and seltzer-like. It left me more thirsty than when I finished it.

Overall not very good.

review_title: Potent but the taste is not for me
review_text:
This is an extremely strong blended drink. It is bitter and strong. I only had one can to experiment with so my views are limited. I opened the can while it was room temperature and took a sip. This was not a pleasant experience. I then poured some over ice and it did taste much better. It was not until I cut the rest of the can with some vanilla flavored soy milk and ice that it tasted "good" to me. On the up side, this small can gave me much fuel for studying for several hours.

Final impression: I would not buy this on a regular basis but would consider using it for a long study session. Not a terrible product but not for me.

Illy's ready-made coffee is the perfect espresso-style drink for someone on the go, with no time to brew a cup. Made with a distinct blend of 100% Arabica coffee, this bold beverage has a fresh coffee taste that's both cool and refreshing.

It's flavored with just enough sweetness to make it enjoyable, but not so much that it's no longer coffee. It has an authentic European flavor to it and contains only natural ingredients. The 6.8 oz. can has only 45 calories. It tastes good either cold or warmed.

Illy issimo caffè Italian espresso style coffee drink is a 6.8 fl. oz. (200 ml) blast of sweetened caffeine in a can.

1930s Italy under the rule of Mussolini greatly contributed to the development of modern coffee culture, improved coffee-making, and new types of coffee-making equipment. The Horn of Africa (where coffee originated) was under Italian colonization and companies such as illy and Bialetti were founded.

In that tradition, this drink is now made in Denmark under the issimo brand from illy and distributed in the U.S. by Coca-Cola.

This canned cappuccino has a slightly bitter dark roast coffee taste with the right amount of sugar and a pleasant mouthfeel. It's not as good as freshly made espresso but it's not bad at all. I do prefer the illy issimo cappucino as a treat.

review_title: Strong espresso flavor with a hint of milk
review_text:
Strong espresso taste with a hint of mil, but a tiny bit bitter for me, yet not as much as the cappuccino flavor. If you like a little bitterness, then you'll prolly love this. Thankfully no can taste, which was a concern of mine. I prefer a bit more milk in mine (soy or rice).

Otherwise not much to say - plain, no flavors, although I'm sure you could add your own if you want i, but taste fine just like it is.

The bitterness was just a hint, which many regular espresso drinkers probably wouldn't notice - for me, it was enough to take off a star, but was still good. Don't know that I'll be buying a lot of it, but for that allergy or headache, when I use that caffeine, it would be great to have around to get rid of those.

There's a lot of flavor packed into this little 6.8 ounce can! You can chill it and enjoy it straight from the can or, as we did, pour it over ice and add some vanilla creamer for a fancier drink. This is a quality product that is from a little known company. Drink with confidence, it's yummy!

This is an 'on the go" pick-me-up coffee drink made by Coca-Cola company.

According to the bottle it's made with 100% Arabica coffee, the coffee is very much espresso -- dark and strong on the coffee. There's added sugar in this so it tastes palatable.

Illy is a top coffee brand in Italy, so I was very interested in trying their pre-packaged espresso. This drink is also pre-sweetened. It was quite a disappointment to take a sip and find that there was absolutely no flavor of coffee at all. And espresso's supposed to be pretty strong. The only taste was that of the sweetener, of which there was far too much. I'll continue to make expresso at home, grinding the beans and using my little stove top pot.

review_title: Got this for the wife, she hated it
review_text: My wife is a coffee drinker, I am not so I got this for her to try and her immediate impressions, it was terrible. She tried another of the illy issimo drinks and felt that tasted watered down, this however was strong but the taste was terrible. Now taste is all subjective so while she hated it you may like it. That being said she does love the starbucks drinks you can buy and this was not on-par with the taste of those according to her. I believe if she wants canned coffee in the future we'll be staying away from this brand.

review_title: Yeesh - kicks like a mule! Tastes like a Imperial Stout
review_text:
This is my second "coffee-in-a-can" from illy issimo - my first being the much sweeter Cappuccino.

I should preface my review by first saying that I am not a coffee drinker - I usually like my coffee in a dessert setting; being nice and sweet and creamy. I knew enough about coffees to know that the espresso would be the darker, more robust and more bitter of the two drinks, but wow - what a punch. I have been on a beer kick lately and many of the darker stout beers say that they have a strong "coffee flavor" which I never understood because I was expecting "coffee" as in the flavor I associate with something like coffee iced cream. After drinking this espresso drink, I now understand the flavor they talk about - and oddly enough, the first thought that came to my mind when I drank this was, "Wow, this tastes like a beer." (not in the boozy sense, mind you - just the bitter bite and flavor overtones).

There is a twinge of sweetness to the drink, but nothing that I would consider having a major impact. The bitterness is pretty impressive considering that this small can has 10g of sugar - to put that into perspective, it has about half the sugar of a normal Coke.

Now... the caffeine part.

I don't really get much caffeine any more - I used to drink tons when I was a kid - going through multiple six-packs of Coke in a week. Nowadays the only caffeine I get is from iced tea at a restaurant (unsweet). So maybe it's because my tolerance is now a bit lower than it used to be, but this thing kicks like a mule. I drank the espresso about three hours after eating lunch, and I would say that I felt the impact within ten minutes of finishing off the can. It stuck with me for about an hour too. Oddly enough, the cappuccino version of this drink took a few hours for me to feel the caffeine high. I checked out the can and found out why... pregnant women and people with heart issues should probably stay very far away from this drink.

Here are some basic caffeine stats from the Mayo Clinic:
Drink Size Caffeine
5-Hour Energy 2 oz. (60 mL) 207 mg
Red Bull 8.4 oz (250 mL) 76-80 mg
Coca-Cola Classic 12 oz. (355 mL) 30-35 mg
Mountain Dew 12 oz. (355 mL) 46-55 mg

This little can is 6.8 fl oz (200mL) and contains 155 mg of caffeine.

If you're a big coffee drinker who takes a lot of their coffee strong and black, these numbers won't come as much of a shock to you since it's pretty much in line with normal brewed coffee. However, if you're no longer a caffeine junkie, don't be surprised if you suddenly feel the need to run a marathon.

My final verdict is that I like this stuff, although in the future I'd probably tend to stick more with the sweeter Mochas and Cappuccinos. If you're not a fan of the bitter coffees, I can't say I'd recommend this drink for you, but I didn't find the flavor as off-putting as many other reviewers seem to have.

review_title: Bitter - Not Sweet and It Has 10 grams of Sugar
review_text:
The ingredients in this product are: coffee, sugar, potassium bicarbonate and potassium citrate. It has 10 grams of sugar. Note this does not have a dairy product ingredient in it.

This is a thin consistency drink with a bold bitter coffee taste. I detect no sweetness at all, although it has 10 grams of sugar.

I like the taste of bold coffee with french roast or cofee and chickory New Orleans style or Vietnamese style coffee drinks. This was bold and strong but a thin consistency and bitter despite the sugar added.

This drink did nothing for me. I prefer a real cup of hot coffee with half and half to give it a creamy consistency, or I like a strong coffee iced coffee drink or I like an espresso based coffee drink or a frozen Frappuccino type of drink. I love strong coffee that's bold. I usually only use one sugar in a large coffee so I don't like it super-sweet by any means. This is just bitter and I rate it 2 stars = I Don't Like It.

There are other iced canned or iced bottled prepared coffee drinks, milk or no milk products that I prefer the taste of such as the ones made by Starbucks (i.e. glass bottled Frappuccino) or the little aluminum cans of espresso drinks such as Starbucks DoubleShot.
My pug is kind of picky but she really took to the Chef Michael's sirloin dry kibble' I gave it to her mixed with her usual kibble and we had no problem with digestive upset.

Our dog Shultz loves the food, in fact he loves it so much he has given up on his self structured eating and now is continually heading back to the bowl for more food.

Unfortunately the large amount of Soy does a number on our dog's intestinal emanations as well as his eating habits so we are going to give away the rest of the bag, after he gets through the mixture in our table top canister. The other issues we have are the artificial ingredients, which may also lend themselves to the gas issues as well.

I believe we will be heading back to the regular dog food we previously purchased. We need a leaner, healthy dog, and a dog food with more natural ingredients will do a much better job.

Dog rating 5 stars
Human Rating 2 stars
Combined 3 stars

I wish the ingredients were a little healthier because my two mini dachshunds really love this food. I should have read the ingredients first. The soy ingredients don't bother me as much as the food coloring does. (Added color (Red 40, Blue 2, Yellow 5, Yellow 6 and other color). The green peas and vegetables in the mix aren't really veggies, but a kibble formed into vegetable shapes and colored to look like vegetables. I wish pet food manufacturers would spend less on making dog food look appetizing to humans and more in making it healthy for our pets.

Although beef is the first ingredient on the list, most of the rest are grain products including soy, corn and rice. One of our dogs sometimes has a sensitive stomach and it's probably all the soy that doesn't always agree. Another ingredient is animal digest which could contain goodness knows what. I think I prefer the limited ingredient types of foods that my dogs normally eat, ones where I can recognize all the ingredients and they don't sound like something I wouldn't want to eat.

When I first put this in my dogs dish she looked at it like it was a coiled rattlesnake. I pretended to eat a handful and she dove right in. ...."Mama is eating it so it must be people food!"....(dogs are so gullible).

I'll admit I was a little turned off by all the "chef Michael....gourmet..grill marks" hype. I think you could color it green and call it roadkill and the dogs wouldn't know the difference. Yeah, I know , all of the hype is for the purchaser.

As for the ingredients, what do I know? The ingredients are listed on the product page if you find that helpful. I sort of think it's like reading the ingredients on "all ground beef patties" then discovering part of the beef is "pink slime". The food is rated 1 star when compared to others which doesn't sound so great to me.

I just have to trust that the researchers and developers at Purina know what is good for animals. The little "bean and potato garnish" are a crunchy dry food and the "meat" looking pieces have sort of a rubbery play-dough texture. Maybe a little easier for older dogs to chew.

The bottom line: My dog eats it and it seems to agree with her. She will usually only eat dry food if I mix a spoonful of science diet cat food in it .

Sometimes I feel sorry for our dogs having to eat the same kibble every day. We can tell that they also hate having the same stuff every day. One of the worst problems for a dog owner is getting them to eat once they become disenchanted with their fare. The problem s that once we lose them, they stay lost. But with this dry food they take an interest and dinnertime becomes competitive once agin as everyone tries to glom the kibble so as to deny the other a good meal. And we'd rather see that than watch them ignore their food altogether.

review_title: Good for a picky eater - not good for a healthy eater
review_text:
"Grilled Sirloin" sounds great for a dog food, and my dog was sniffing the package and followed me from the door to the kitchen with intense interest. He was more interested in this food than many types of treats he has had. So, if your dog is a picky eater who would lose weight rather than eat a food that doesn't interest it (I have had a dog like this), then this might be a viable choice for you in order for you to get your dog to eat.

On the flip side, if your dog has no problems at mealtimes and you want to provide him/her a healthy meal at a fair price, you may want to keep looking. My dog eats 4 cups of his regular food, maintains his weight and energy and has good stools. With this food, he needs about seven cups and a couple more trips outside each day. More food and more waste, because less food/volume is being absorbed by the dog. Less nutrition and more fillers. Pet food manufacturers often split up a filler food into separate types (soy meal/soy flour) so that a meat type will move to first in line of ingredients. First up is "Beef" although not specified as grilled sirloin or not, it is still generally better than foods that start with four types of corn product or a meat byproduct. This also has poultry byproduct meal, plus 3 soy ingredients, 2 wheats, brewers rice, corn, barley, and 4+ artificial colorings. While it is not the worst dog food on the market, it is certainly not the best, and certainly not at this price point. Your dog will probably love this stuff -kind of like how people love junk food.

review_title: Satiates Canines' Desires Both Subtle and Gross
review_text: I break this out as a treat when the family has a big barbecue and our nearly 2-year-old chocolate lab Sampo can barely contain himself, migrating from one person to the next begging for scraps and bones that might kill him. It's a nice, gourmet step up from his usual kibble, and he loves the heck out of it. Same goes for a much smaller dog, my friend's tiny little westie terrier Lucy; obviously she gets a lot less, but she has a lot of allergies and intolerances, and this food agrees with her in every way. You're probably hard pressed to find a dog who wouldn't go ga-ga for this tasty treat.

This is what I can tell you - my dog loves almost all of the food she eats, sneaks or straight out steals (she is a rescue dog with food issues). I cannot honestly tell you anything about this food (not having tried it myself) except that my dog loves it and snarfs it down.

After looking at it on the package and than in the bowl my wife did make the comment that this dog food looks better than a lot of the stews and casseroles we have eaten.

I perfectly understand that the marketing of pet products is directed to the pet owner. I have never actually had a pet demand a certain brand of pet food-- I do have cats who refuse to eat pate style cat food, which I think may be my own fault for giving in to them and buying the sliced bits in gravy when they turned their little kitty noses up at the pate.

But anyway, the dogs definitely had a way of eating this dog food. The bits that represented steak went first. The last bit was the green things-- which is kind of amusing because I once had a dog who absolutely refused to eat the green round things in Beneful. She would delicately pick out all of the green things and leave them scattered around her bowl. So when I found the green things from this brand scattered around I wondered if Lucy's ghost had shown up to protest. Shortly after that I noticed that one of the dogs had finally eaten them.

No one developed any stomach problems or itchies after eating it so it has a thumbs up from a human and pricked ears from three dogs.

I have two min. schnauzers and they tend to be picky eaters.  I was a little reluctant to try this, but am glad I did. They really seem to like Che Michael's!  Thank you Amazon. And having the convienence of having the dog food delivered to the front door is so great!

review_title: Dog enjoyed it but ingredients no better than any other Purina brand - Lotsa CORN, WHEAT & GLUTEN
review_text:
The images on the bag make this Premium Purina dog food look well worth the price but a quick look at the Ingredients list should warn you that if you are gonna spend extra money on your dog's food, you might as well go for the brands that DON'T fake you out with photos of sirloin steak and fake green beans formed from corn & dehydrated green beans. I'll be truthful - my dog loved this and ate it happily. I mixed it it with his regular dog food and he just gobbled it right up. However, my dog doesn't do well on foods loaded with grains so I won't likely be buying this despite how much he loved it. Here are the ingredients in order by weight:

Beef - good to see it's the Number 1 ingredient but from her, it gets sketchy
Soybean meal
Soy Flour
Animal fat
Brewers Rice (an empty calorie filler leftover from Beer making process)
Soy Protein Concentrate
Corn Gluten Meal (another filler)
Ground Yellow Corn (filler)
Glycerin
Poultry By Product - (ground up bones and feathers)
Ground Wheat
Animal Digest (??? I think I know what this is and it makes me sick)
Pearled Barley (Grains again)
Calcium Carbonate (ground up rocks)
Calcium Phosphate (ground up rocks)
Salt
Grilled Siloin Steak FLAVOR (no meat)
Dried Grean Beans
Dried Potatoes
Sulfur, Vitamin E,
Choline Chloride,
Zinc Sulfate, Ferrous Sulfate (both colorants)
Added colors - about 5
Niacin
Wheat Flour (grains again)
and so on and so forth.. the same as basically what's in Beneful.

My advice - if you have to go with a Grocery Store brand, don't be folled by a fancy photo on the bag of Sirloin Steak. Compare the ingredients and buy what you can get the most of for your money IF YOUR DOG CAN EAT THAT STUFF. Mine can but I still go the extra mile and try and by a more meat based diet. While I was pleased that Beef was the first ingredient, I prefer to see the first few ingreidents be meat and never to see fillers like Corn and Brewers Rice.

So 2 stars for taste, 1 star for being the same as every grocery store brand from Purina who makes this and two stars OFF for deceptive packaging and advertising. READ THE LABELS!

review_title: Bag implies high-quality food, ingredients scream junk food
review_text: I think this dog food is a complete scam.  The bag claims "well-rounded meals for adult dogs."  This stuff is well-rounded only if you consider a fast food diet as a well-rounded diet.  Beef may be the first ingredient, but who knows what quality it is and it is directly followed by soybean meal, soy flour, preserved animal fat, brewers rice, soy protein concentrate, corn gluten meal, ground yellow corn, glycerin, poultry by-product meal, ground wheat, animal digest.  The list goes on of junk food for dogs with some artificial flavors and coloring added in also.  They are counting on pretty packaging with healthy claims distracting people from the actual ingredient list that contradicts those claims.  The feeding instructions say that you should feed your dog 1 cup for each 10 pounds of body weight, which means my 70 pound Lab would go through 7 cups of this junk food a day and at 22 cups of it a bag, would last her 3 days.  So this would not only be bad for her health but also bad for my wallet.  I can get a bag of quality grain-free food for her for significantly less than what it would cost me to feed her this for a month.

review_title: There are more nutritious options out there ~~~~
review_text:
I have a 1.5 -year-old, 60-pound Boxer/Pitt Mix she loved the food; gobbled it right up. However, I then did some additional research online and was surprised to discover that this dog food probably isn't the most healthy nor nutritious thing to feed my Joy-Joy. Also I was very unhappy to discover that it contained artificial coloring this has been known to lead to bladder, and/or urinary track issues.

My dog also seemed hungry even if we fed her the recommended amount; 1 cup per 10 pounds (6 cups).

I think we will stick with Blue Buffalo Large Breed Puppy Dry Food, Chicken and Rice Recipe, 30-Pound Bag. Joy-Joy loves the favor and it is what my vet recommended.

I think this dog food is best as more of a treat than a regular diet! The price is a bit expensive for my tastes, and as much our dogs enjoy it, they'd literally eat us out of house and home if we used this as an everyday food for them.

Our indoor dog, an Olde English Bulldogge, suffers from some extreme gas. Maybe I should say WE suffer from his extreme gas! After seeing some of the other reviews concerning soy, I realize that's something we need to cut from his diet. This food has a great deal of soy in it.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend using this as an everyday food for your dogs.

review_title: She LOVED the taste, but not so healthy
review_text:
I will echo the concerns about the healthiness of this product but without question, my dog ate this food like nothing else I've given her. The odor is
not overly strong and it does appear to be a nice mix of meat and vegetables. I will be using this as a supplement to her normal dog food, which is much healthier but for a little treat, I'll mix this in with her food. The pellets are small enough that you could use these bits as a snack and not for the principal meal.

I can't/won't feed this to my own dogs because of food allergies, and there's the mysterious "animal fat" and "animal digest" in this ingredient list which makes me a little nervous about which animal it came from. Really, the ingredient list is terrible, it's a bunch of leftover food waste products made into dog food. Beef is the first ingredient in the list, but when you add up all the forms of soy, corn, and wheat in the ingredient list, there's more junk in this dog food than beef.

*BUT*, my family's dog is a picky eater and this Chef Michael's dog food is perfect for her because she's used to treats and flavorful table scraps (bad, bad habit that I don't approve of) and she snubs healthier kibbles. Salt makes this kibble tasty. With the ingredient list, this kibble reminds me of salted kinda-meaty Cheetos, complete with unnecessary food colorings.

For my own dogs, this would be a 1-star food (honestly, I think this is junk and overpriced too for what it is), but this food does have its uses if you don't really mind what's in it and you have a picky dog and need extra flavorings to entice them to eat dry dog food.

I don't know about your dogs, but my two (a Parson's Jack-mix and moyen Poodle) are nose driven when it comes to chow. Consequently it is VERY important that I be able to keep their food fresh and odor-ful. Chef Michael's dog food isn't resealable. And that's a big one-star drop for me.

As far as APPEARANCE it's okay. The meaty-looking bits look like giant rough extruded fake-bacon bits. And they are interspersed with green and light brown veggie looking bits. My dogs don't like the latter, at all.

The ODOR isn't all that pleasant to me, but it's not a problem because I can't smell the kibble until my nose is right in the bowl. My little Jack seems drawn to the smell. Rodger-Pippin isn't so sure.

My final STAR-DROP came from the use of "Animal Digest". On the surface of it, Animal Digest doesn't sound so bad. It's a broth made from animal parts. However, the 'parts' can be anything, including road-kill, and since Purina gets many of their ingredients from China I don't think I'd be comfortable with feeding my family's beloved members this food on a longterm basis.

Pam T~
mom & fur-mom

This dog food is a little spendy for the quality but it definitely appeals to my dog's taste. So we have been using it as a little "appetizer" mixed in with the rest of her dinner, on the nights when her appetite is sluggish due to the weather. The kibbles are nice and small for little dogs (she's about 9 lbs).

review_title: My dogs love it, but the ingredient list gives me paws...ahem, pause
review_text:
Chef Michael might be a fictional character in the same vein as Aunt Jemima and the Keebler Elves, but that doesn't excuse him from putting some truly nasty ingredients into his Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food. So many other reviewers have pointed out the list of dubious ingredients that it doesn't pay to duplicate them again, but I urge you to take a long, hard look at that list before you commit to purchasing this item.

Nutrition aside, this is a very tasty food item based on my dogs' response to finding it in their bowl. Frankly, they went bonkers over Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food. I'm probably not going to make this part of their regular diet, but I will continue using it as a treat.

Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin food was a big hit with my dog. It has a variety of pieces, meat and vegetables, soft and crunchy. It has big chunks that are meant to emulate real pieces of beef. My dog seemed to especially like those. He took each piece out of the bowl and chewed it up in the same manner he would eat a big piece of meat. When I first put some of this food in his bowl, he ate it up in no time and came sniffing around the bag for more. He's a big dog and eats a couple of good sized scoops of dry food each day, so this 4.5 pound bag lasted less than a week. It would last longer for a smaller dog and I'll buy a bigger bag next time I get some.

The only thing I don't like about this dog food is the bag. It has to be cut open, which is slightly less convenient than just ripping it or pulling on a string, but not a big deal. I also wish the bag were resealable with a Ziploc-type closure. I have to either transfer this food to another container once opened, or fold it up just so and push the open end against the wall to keep it shut. The bag, however, is not a deciding factor when I'm looking for a food my dog enjoys. I'll certainly consider this dog food in the future.

So first things first, My dogs loved it. They went for this food vs their regular food (lamb and rice flavored kibble).
But what this does is appeal to the owner who will visually agree to the packaging and the idea of feeding sirloin to their pets.
All in all, this is a fancy type of dog food, that smells very strongly (makes dogs love it more), but it as taken over the pantry and do not want this, therefore becoming unappealing to the owner.
The food is slightly rubbery, and seems to be semi-dry, vs regular dry dog food.
Also the package says to feed your dog 1 cup for every 10 lbs, that means my dogs would be eating 8 cups a day...each! I disagree with this.
This is a good treat for my dogs but prefer not to spoil them with this food.
Your dogs will love it, it just depends if you want to spend on and feed them this food.

review_title: You're dogs will love it, owners will love it for the price but it may not be the healthiest...
review_text:
When it comes to dog food, as you can see with the many reviews on Purina Chef Michael's products, you have passionate pet owners who are concerned about their dogs health and feeding them the best food possible.

I admire pet owners who can do just that, as I know many who prefer to cook their dogs meal to those who will splurge in order to make sure their dogs eat the best and are healthy. But with today's economy, I also know that there are owners who can't cook, can't splurge and try to look for the best price that they can to feed their dog(s).

Purina's Chef Michels brand sounds like gourmet food for the dogs. But looking at the price, how can gourmet food be so cheap? Well, for the Grilled Sirloin Steak Flavor dog food which comes with potato & green bean garnishes, there is no doubt that many dogs will eat it.

Ingredients are: Beef, soybean meal, soy flour, animal fat preserved with mixed-tocopherols (form of Vitamin E), brewers rice, soy protein concentrate, corn gluten meal, ground yellow corn, glycerin, poultry by-product meal, ground wheat, animal digest, pearled barley, salt, calcium carbonate, calcium phosphate, natural filet mignon flavor, dried green beans, dried potatoes, added color (Red 40, Blue 2, Yellow 5, Yellow 6 and other color), sulfur, zinc sulfate, Vitamin E supplement, ferrous sulfate and many more.

My small adult Pug-tzu's love eating this dry dog food. It's small and at first they sniffed it but after 10 minutes or so, they began scarfing it down. I did mix it with other dog food but on its own, I'm sure they enjoy it. And what I like about it is that Amazon offers it for under $10, Purina does say they use real beef and the crunchy kibbles includes 23 essential vitamins and minerals. Granted, after eating this, they also tend to have more stools. I also want to note that my dogs did not produce any horrid flatulence after eating this dog food, like others have reported.

JUDGMENT CALL:

I'm not an erudite when it comes to what is healthy for dogs and what isn't. There are many reviews from hardcore dog lovers that you can read on this product to know that many have chimed in and called this "junk food" for their dogs.

But I also feel that there are many people out there who are dog owners who can't afford to pay so much for their dog's food and the price of this dry dog food is quite appealing. Purina does claim this particular Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin dry dog food does include 23 essential vitamins and nutrients.

So, for the pet owners who are very budget-conscious, are looking for dry dog food that their small dogs will enjoy but also getting the essential vitamins in their meal, then Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog food may be for you.

review_title: My dogs give it two paws up!
review_text: My dogs tend to have sensitive stomachs and many dog foods cause them to get sick. We tried to Costco brand and we had trouble, so I was hesitant to try Chef Michael's. But, I hated to keep buying the dog food from the vet. They are so expensive! When I opened the bag and was surprised that it didn't have that odor that many dog foods have. It actually smelled kind of good. The true test would be how my dogs liked it and if it caused gas and an upset stomach. They ate the food up immediately and were searching for more. Fortunately,Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin didn't upset their stomach one bit! No gas, good solid poop and happy dogs! My only complaint is that the bag doesn't have a gripper seal. I had to find another container to keep it in, which is a bit of a bummer, but I'd much rather find a container than clean up after a sick dog. I'll be sure to get this food again in the future.

review_title: Not as good as it could be"'
review_text: I chose this dog food seeing grilled sirloin on the description.I figured the dogs would like it alot.Well,they sure did""They scarfed it down so fast it was as if we hadnt fed them in a week.Its very soft food and would be good for older dogs that have messed up teeth and cant chew very well.The ingredients could be alot better.The first ingredient is beef and thats good for them.Ingredients are listed with the main ingredient first just as all food products are.The rest is a list of all kinds of stuff most likely not to good for them.I see many people knocking it and thats fine.I would bet they didnt throw it away though""Ten bucks is a little pricey for 4.5 pounds of food i feel.I guess im a cheepskate""I most likely would not buy it.Sorry purina.

review_title: My dog likes it a lot
review_text:
I have a finicky Border collie/Golden Retriever cross, and he's been tired of Science Diet, so I tried out Chef Michael's.

He likes it a *lot*. So, rank that as a plus. He seems to like this brand more than any other dog food brand.

On the minus side, he's smelling a bit weird now, on occasion. He's usually odor free 24/7, so that's a change for him. I'll see if that phases passes, and if it does, I'll stick with Chef Michael's. Obviously, that's what my dog would like, but I can be finicky, too.

Recommended.

We have the pickiest dog on earth. It took us 3 years to find a food that he would eat a full bowl of on a consistent basis! When this came and we filled his bowl with it the first time, I fully expected him to possibly take a couple of bites then refuse to eat any more. I was shocked when he ate the entire bowl then went to his food container, basicly asking for more. I gave him another cup of the food, he ate most of that before he laid down again. I was thrilled to find another food that he liked!
After 3 or 4 days of him eating this food, he started having REALLY bad gas. Imagine a 100 lb dog with bad gas laying next to where you are sitting on the couch! Nevermind, you don't want to imagine that but you get my point. After 4 days of dealing with the gas from hell we put him back on his old food. Viola, gas was gone! Thank God! I don't know if that's a common reaction to the food but it certainly didn't agree with our dog's tummy. Good news is that the outside cats like it and if they have gas, too, I don't have to deal with it. ;-)

It really looked like a bowl of stew.  My dogs seemed to scarf it down, which was a relief.  My wowser, jack, only ever seems to eat blue without me having to dress his food up with grated meat or cheese.  Pepper will eat anything so it didn't surprise me that she enjoyed this just as much as blue or nature's choice.

This dog food ( dry kibble) is. So popular with our dogs! and it is practically
odorless, so we can keep a bowl in our bedroom for nighttime snacking, which keep our dogs quite all night.

I won't dispute the fact that Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin is somewhat expensive and may not be the healthiest choice in dry dog food, but there is no denying the fact that dogs love it. Heck, I have 2 cats and even they enjoy snacking on it when the dog isn't around. Perhaps it isn't ideal nutrition, but I don't think it is as bad as some other reviewers have made it out to be. In any event, this is more of a treat food than a diet staple, and when viewed in that light, it is actually healthier and much more cost effective than many of those little packages of doggie treats that line the grocery store shelves.

Place a serving of this next to a bowl of "healthy" store brand dog food and there is no comparison. Aesthetically it looks better, but I know that isn't what dogs care about. The bowl of Chef Michael's food will be eaten first every time. My suggestion is to either mix it in with your regular dry food, or use it as a treat. If you are overly concerned by the ingredients in your pet's food, then you may find issue with this brand. Also, there is no "zip-lock" to re-seal it so you'll need a large, strong clip to keep the bag closed. Or you can use an large plastic container like I do. Otherwise, this pet food gets two paws up!

I had both of my golden retrievers try the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food to see if they would like it. The 8 month old overgrown puppy will eat almost anything and he loved this dog food, which I expected him to do. I wasn't so sure about the 9 year old "picky" eater, but she really liked this food, as well! She will eat her regular dry kibble, but not until she is really hungry, and she will often skip one of her twice daily feedings after checking to see what is in her food bowl. The morning she found Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin in her dish, she sniffed it, looked at me (I'm pretty sure she smiled) and proceeded to gobble up the food. Of course her "brother" had already inhaled his and was hoping for more!
This dry food is not shaped like regular kibble, in that every piece does not look or feel the same. The best way I can describe it is to say that it looks like "dehydrated" beef stew. The pieces of meat are irregularly shaped and flatter than most kibble, and the veggies (mainly peas and carrots) really look like vegetables. I would describe the texture as thick, solid "flakes" rather than round or square pieces of kibble. I detected no odor, although it must smell wonderful to the dogs.
I have not used the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin for the dog's regular feedings as one dog is still eating puppy food and the other eats senior formula, so I can't really comment on the nutrition value, or how this food affects their canine digestive tracts. What I can comment upon, is how much both dogs loved this food. I've been using a handful at a time as "training rewards" and both dogs like the Chef Michael's food as much as their regular treats. We can keep the dogs' regular bags of food on a closet floor to which the dogs have full access, but I've had to hide the Chef Michael's food, since I found a large golden head in the bag! A 4.5 bag is not going to last very long at our house.
I plan to discuss the Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Food with my vet before feeding it to the dogs on a regular basis, but if she oks it, I will definitely purchase this dry food and add another star to my rating. (Hopefully, it is also sold in a 20lb or 40lb size). Until then, I'll use it as treats for the dogs, or for "dessert" on top of their present food. If my "picky dog," who often refuses regular dog treats, eats Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin Dry Dog Food, it's obviously yummy!

review_title: My Dog Loves The Beef, The Brown Hard Pieces Not So Much
review_text:
I like that this dog food has beef chunks and vegetables in it. I know some people are upset about the soy, but I don't see it as an issue with my chihuahua "Tequila". Tequila is very picky about his dog food and does not eat hard brown dog food for some reason. With this dog food being multi-colored and having beef pieces I was hoping he would eat all of it.

Tequila perked up the second I opened the bag. You could tell that he loved the smell. I gave him one of the beef chunks and he immediately devoured it. I filled his bowl with the food and he excitedly ran over to it and started eating. When I walked into the kitchen later, there were hard brown chunks of food placed everywhere throughout the room. Dang dog! He did eat everything else in the bowl. So, he likes it better than a lot of other dog foods. As far as I know, there is not a dog food on the market that he will eat all of....so it gets four paws up from him. I would buy this food for my pup again.

My dog is really picky about what dry food she'll eat. It was only because I trusted the brand so much that I was willing to give it a try and I am happy I did.
Daisy has liked the food since her very first bowl - I didn't have to mix it with her old food and try to sneak it to her - really unusual for her.
I like the different sized pieces that are in the bag because the shapes seemed to make her eat more slowly, they probably cleaned her teeth good, and she seemed to get full on less food than what I was giving her before.
So far we have only tried 1 bag and part of a second but there have been no health issues and my trust in the Purina brand has paid off.

review_title: A deeper, in-depth look at the ingredients indicate red flags
review_text:
On the outside, it's great that my dog seems to enjoy this food. However, there is no reason to buy this food for your dog, knowing that there is by product, corn gluten, and animal digest. Despite the price, I would not recommend this dog food to any dog owner, especially with the by product.

By product may consist a variety of (via Dogadvisor[dot]com)

Feet
Backs
Livers
Lungs
Heads
Brains
Spleen
Frames
Kidneys
Stomachs
Intestines
Undeveloped eggs

It is unacceptable to use animal waste into dog food.

I recommend brands that do not use animal by-product at all: Blue buffalo, natural choice, innovo.

Get your act together, Purina. Ditch the cheap, easy way of production and use quality ingredients.

Our dogs' diet is largely people food as my brother spends his day cooking. However, we always put out a bowl of good dry dog food for them when they aren't interested in our meals (been on a low red meat quick lately to keep the cholesterol under control).

Although the ingredients aren't quite as good as the premium brand I've been giving them, I certainly don't consider it poison as some reviewers have stated. If soybeans are good enough for menopausal women, why would you think it's going to harm your dog? It might cause bloating but it won't kill them.

So I give it a three as adequate and the dogs seemed to enjoy it.

review_title: Dog Wolfs This Down and Need to Monitor the Intake
review_text: If you put a bowl of this in front of my dog, he will gobble the whole thing up - he really likes, it.  I'm not too sure that is a good thing as, for example, he usually is a self-regulated eater and eats when he is hungry vs. sitting down to what I would compare in human terms of a bowl of buttery popcorn.  I am now only giving him a small portion of this food as a "treat" every now and then and have put him back on his normal, healthier dog food.

There are two components of a review about dog food for me: Do the dogs like it? And is it good for them?

To answer the first, my dogs LOVE it. We had just finished a bag of feed so I opened this and they instantly started smelling the air as I poured it from the bag into their feed container. From there I scooped out their usual quantity into each bowl and where they usually follow me with interest to where I set the bowls down for them to eat, this time they fairly pranced - leaping up and down with excitement at the "treat" that was in store for them. On their old food, they would eat until they were full but often wander away with a little food left in the bottom to come back to later. This time, they finished the bowl and then licked it clean. So it certainly passed the taste test.

Next is the question as to whether or not it is good for them. I gave it a 4 because the overall ingredients are not terrible. The first ingredient is meat - the first rule of thumb for me in any pet food. However the second two ingredients are soy products, followed by brewers rice, more soy and then corn. Included in the ingredients is also wheat. So although it starts well, with Beef as the first ingredient, in the end it is bulked out by grains of all sorts, which lower the production costs for the manufacturer and keep the food priced lower for the consumer but also lowers the nutritional benefit to the animal.

One last comment. My first impression when I scooped the food into the bowls was that it is designed to look like a stew. Visually, it contains brown chunks - the meat - small green balls - the peas - and similarly sized yellow balls - the corn. The problem is that a bowl of stew containing meat, peas and corn sounds yummy to us and is, in fact, designed to appeal to US visually - but is NOT a diet I would feed my dogs. And, since dogs rely on smell more than vision, the visual appeal would be lost on them. So I guess I didn't really appreciate what felt like a "trick" to get us to think of this as a good wholesome food for the dogs.

If you feed your dog Supermarket grade kibble, then this might be a step up for your dog in taste if not nutrition. Two of my dogs loved it, the third, who has a sensitive stomach, didn't really care for it. It has nuggets that look like vegetables and others that look like bits of meat although the distinction is purely cosmetic. The meaty bits are supposed to be tender but they felt as hard and crunchy as the rest of the nuggets.

Also, the protein content is pretty high at a minimum of 28%. I know, we have been told by dog food companies of late, that our dogs crave meat and lots of it. The truth of the matter is that too much protein can damage your dog's kidneys. Sadly, we found this out the hard way with our beloved Shiloh. The pain and expense of having a dog suffer through kidney failure is significant and not something I would want to go through again. Our vet told us that we should switch to a kibble with a protein content in the range of 18-20% and to get out of the habit of feeding our dogs high protein treats like jerky and pig's ears. I don't know, but you might want to talk to your vet about it before switching.

Now on the other hand, if you feed your dog premium dog food or organic premium dog food, then I would definately not advise switching. Our vet also recommends organic natural dog food based on a suspected link between preservatives and fillers used in cheaper dog food and certain types of cancer in dogs. Some articles I've read in various dog magazines have also reported the link between preservatives in dog food and cancer in dogs. Again, you might want to discuss this with your vet. Also, FYI I'm suspicious of any vet who tends to only recommend the brand of dog food that they sell at their office. So, if this happens to you you might want to do your own research on line just make sure your truely getting an unbiased opinion.

So anyway, I had been feeding our dogs the "good stuff" for several years but my husband would frequently comment (which in guy speak is like complaining) on the doggy food bill. He ultimately suggested that we give this stuff a try because, after all, Chef Michael feeds it to his dog. So I tried it and well, I'm sorry to have to tell you this dear but we're switching back to the premium stuff.

My dog doesn't always like new food.  I think she really liked this Chef Michael's food. I checked out the ingredients and it along w/ meat for protien and veggies it says it contains 23 essential vitamins and minerals.  It also contains cruncy kibble. I can't taste it so of course I was relying on my dog's willingness to eat it when put in her bowl. I must admit the thing that I loved the best was that it didn't stink like most dog food/kibble.  Dry dog food really stinks to me no matter what brand I've tried but this didn't have that stinky smell. I give this a thumbs up and will be trying it out. Haven't checked the price to compare to others but as long as it's not double the price I will be purchasing another bag.

Dog food like this is made for the human palate. Just look at the bag...since when can dog's read? If they could they would demand real ingredients with no fillers. Remember your mutt will generally eat anything you will or make funny noises because it smells good. Good dog food does not smell good.

I did let my mutts try a handful. True, they swallowed it right down, but the gas and diarrhea that followed was horrendous. The gas was so bad I left the house and let my wife deal with it.

No more junk food for my mutts.

Although the bag is pretty average, this dog food is not, it is definitely a higher end dog food, a cut above the usual dry dog food and and has a fresh looking appearance to it.
So how did it taste? well, my dogs seemed to like it, I have noticed they seem to eat "dry" dog food when they are hungry rather than when I serve it, however, I they ate this when I served it, not sure a nibble, they would finish it all.
A good product, more expensive that typical dog food but if you can afford it, it won't go to waste!

review_title: My picky dog did not like it.
review_text: When I saw this, I thought it would be rather appealing to dogs.  It looks as though it is full of taste and flavorful with the different tastes and textures combined.  When I filled my shih tzu's bowl with this, however, he simply looked at me, down at the bowl, gave it a sniff and walked away.  Granted, he is a very very very picky dog.  So far the only dog food that I have found that he really loves is Purina Beneful.  I have tried giving him this a couple of times and none of the times has he taken any interest in eating it.  Our cats, on the other hand, have nibbled on it and they don't seem to mind it.  I think this will end up going out to our big outside dogs - they love and eat anything, lol.  Bottom line, I will not be purchasing this in the future.

review_title: Pros & cons, but the pros win out.
review_text:
The # 1 ingredient is beef -- a rarity in today's bagged dog food -- but with the price running a little over $2 per pound, I'm not going to use this in place of the high quality kibble I've been feeding my dogs (for which I pay about $1 per pound). However, my dogs LOVE this stuff, so I see two good uses for it:

1. Add a small handful as a flavor booster to their regular kibble.

2. Because it's easy to handle plus chewy and not crunchy, it makes for great rewards during agility training.

If I were using it strictly for their regular food I'd give it a lower rating (because of price), but for the purposes I just stated, I think it's excellent and therefore I'll give five stars. A bag of this stuff on hand is a lot cheaper than the other products I've been using for agility training rewards!

review_title: Looks Nice, My Dog Likes it, Not Great Nutrition Though
review_text:
I often wonder how much time is invested in making dog food look like something we feel better about giving to our pets. This food looks nice, different colors, 'meaty' looking moist chunks and my dog loves eating it.

It's over $2 a pound so it should be great right?

But, after reading up on the food at dog food advisor dot com I would never get this food again. It can be deceiving that beef is the first ingredient. But as it is explained in the review at dog food advisor, that is the weight of the beef before drying and processing - which contains a lot of water. So after processing, it is probably a much lower percentage of ingredient. Then there were other questionable ingredients including animal fat - the origin can be from a number of gross places, and a high corn meal content.

So, I think much of the high price comes from the processing to make it look better to us and therefore make us feel better giving it to our dogs.

I think I'm going back to my 4/5 star Kirkland dog food.

My two dogs loved this! I agree that the ingredients are not much better than Old Roy, Walmart's brand, but my dogs loved it. Okay, they woofed it down so fast, I'm not sure they actually tasted it, but their bowls were so clean I just put them back in the cupboard because it's chili night here. ;o)

Sheri Gill

review_title: Neither the dog nor I cared much for this
review_text:
I have a large mutt who is a fairly fussy eater. When I was offered the opportunity to review this dog food, I thought Buck was in for a treat from some fancy dog food - a nice change from the usual kibble. And, my first impression, when I opened the bag of dog food, was "Oh, this looks good."

But, it was all downhill from there. First I looked on the bag to see how much I was supposed to feed my dog. One cup per 10 pounds. One cup per 10 pounds! That's 8 cups/day for my large dog. There's a lot of filler in this dog food. I feed 3 1/2 cups/day of my regular dog food.

So, I thought maybe the Chef Michael's would be better used as a replacement for just a small portion of the regular food to give Buck a treat. Based on the appearance, I was sure it must taste good. Much to my surprise, my dog did not really care for this dog food. He didn't hate it and did eventually eat what I put out, but was not at all enthusiastic about it.

review_title: I use it as a TRAINING TREAT, not a meal
review_text: My dogs really like this food.  It is a great reward during training.  It's hard to find a good variety of nutritionally balanced training treats, so I was happy to find this.  The yellow and green kibbles are of a typical kibble texture and a nice size for a treat for a dog up to about 50 pounds.  The softer, squishy "meaty" looking pieces are of variable size.  Most are larger than the hard kibbles.  Some are quite small -- there will be a very small portion of the bag that ends up as topping for a meal.  Nutritionally and economically, it is not as good as the Eukanubia I use as my dogs' main diet.  So I do recommend this for use as a training treat!

After reading all the reviews I thought my dog was going to scarf this food down. He didn't and because of that I know he didn't really love it. Also, this food smells really bad. I don't know if I just never notices bad dog food smell before but as I was pouring this into his bowl, I was like "Ewwww". I will not buy this food for my dog.

I put a bowl of this out next to our dog's other food, also Purina brand.  The dog clearly preferred this food and finished the entire bowl.  I found the food odd looking -- instead of typical little chunks of kibble, this food had pieces that look like meat, with scraggly edges and such.  I have no idea if dogs care what their food looks like -- but they did seem to enjoy eating this.  I wish the bag had a zip-lock closure, but other than that, no complaints.

review_title: If dogs see in black and white, why is the food so COLORFUL?
review_text:
This is dog food and therefore, I did not consume it myself -- however, based on the colors and shapes of the kibbles, I think Chef Michael assumes that I will.

My dogs ate the food just fine -- no digestive issues and no real complaints... but they are dogs... they would eat out of my cat's litter box if I let them.

What struck me as a human is how colorful the kibbles are -- lots of reds and greens. Really? I'm guessing that isn't natural food color there but added to make the food look more appetizing to humans. I'm not a natural health food nut by any stretch of the imagination but even the skeptic in me thinks that at a minimum, they are spending a lot of money on the appearance of the food where I would rather know that that money was going towards nutrition.

Finally, I can't be sure but I do believe my dogs are actually "passing a lot more gas" since they have been eating this food. If that is true, that is yet another reason not to use this food in the long run... my house is stinky enough as it is without the contributions of my dogs.

[NCJVR]

review_title: Can be a problem if your dog normally eats dry food
review_text:
Technically this should be a 5 star rated product because dogs devour it. But, it can be a huge problem if your dg is normally accustomed t more traditionl dry food. It's almost as if this is like a kid eating too much candy.

But in all seriousness, it's well made and dogs will like it - way too much. So be careful; otherwise you'll have a problem transitioning back to regular dry food.

review_title: Definitely worth trying for your dog
review_text:
I must say that in my dog's 2+ year lifetime so far, Chef Michael's Dry dog food is the ONLY food that my dog has liked more than once. We made a mistake and fed our dog human food for the majority of his lifetime, which he then developed an obvious taste for people food and would turn down any dog food we tried to feed him. We've tried tons of $$$ worth of dog food that he just sniffed and left, and Chef Michael's he actually eats when hes hungry.

We went through two rotisserie chicken bags that he finished and now he's about halfway done with the beef one. I cannot tell which one my dog prefers but I would highly recommend to buy both of them to give yours a variety rather than just one flavor for their lifetime.

I would 100% recommend this dog food for your dog. You can find it in your local supermarket (try different ones if one doesn't carry it) or obviously buy it on amazon.

Forgive me ahead of time if this review gets into "too much information" territory, but yes, I'm going to discuss dog poop here. :-)

I've had difficulty finding a dog food that:
a) my dog likes and
b) doesn't also cause what we call in our house...the dreaded Dog-arrhea!

As a result of far too many clean ups - on the floor, on the carpet, on little dog feet, on our long-haired dog's posterior, I've stuck to a very boring but reliable kibble. The result, she eats because she's hungry, but doesn't really enjoy it.

Well, I can say that all that has changed!

First and foremost, Chef Michael's dog food actually looks good. Now, while I don't think the dog cares what the food looks like, it's still impressive for the doggie owner.

Second, it actually smells good. No dog food reek here.

Third, the dog loves it. From a dog who usually picks at her food, I now have a dog who devours her food. LOL - as a matter of fact, I was awakened to the sound of the dog food bowl being pushed across the kitchen floor as someone looked for more food!

And fourth and finally - the scoop on the poop! I'm happy to say that the Dog-arrhea that usually comes with a change in food is non-existent. Since I'm the one who has to scoop the poop before the gardener comes every week, let me just say that back yard clean up is a breeze. And when the dog uses the pads on occasion, it's a super easy - and not at all smelly - clean up.

So, with apologies for all the images this review may have brought to mind, but this is a really great dog food!

If one is looking to purchase this bag of dog food (I received one to review), the price is a bit high for the size bag considering the filler present within the food. The description makes a big deal out of the main ingredient being beef, but this is quickly rendered unimportant when one sees that almost the entire remainder of the bag is filler...including food coloring....perhaps to make the product more palatable to the server instead of the eater?

This food can also help contribute to gas...I'm presuming that is because of the two different types of soy filler that follow neck and neck behind beef as the primary ingredients.

I would agree with other users that Chef Michael's is best left as a treat/reward food as it breaks up a diet and may even create in-fighting for the last scraps of food...even if your pups don't usually go in for that sort of thing.

Unless you are already feeding your dog a low end dog food, Chef Michael's Grilled Sirloin is not something I'd recommend feeding to your pet.

I try to feed our dog better grade dog food. Right now he is eating Castor and Pollux Natural Ultramix. There are several other high quality pet foods available.

If you'd rather skip this review and are looking for a better quality dog food, there are several out there, some of which strive to serve "natural/organic" products. Here are justa few, listed alphabetically: Blue Buffalo, Castor and Pollux, Merrick (who recently merged with Castor and Pollux), and Wellness.

Chef Michael's is a Purina product. While not trying to malign Purina, I am not aware of any better quality dog foods they produce.

The ingredients, in order, directly from the label:
